title: Annihilationism
intro:
Hypothesis: The wicked will be completely destroyed and cease to exist.

Annihilationism is also called conditional immortality, because it holds that only the saved will be granted eternal life, while the wicked will simply cease to exist. This is in contrast to the majority view of eternal conscious torment in Hell.

evidence.head: Fear Him Who Can Destroy Both Soul and Body in Hell
evidence.short: Jesus tells people to fear God, who can "destroy both body and soul in hell."
evidence.details:
Proponents argue that the most natural reading of this is that both the body and soul cease to exist.

Critics argue that ἀπόλλυμι (apollumi, 'to destroy') can also mean 'to ruin' or 'to lose', and that the soul can be "destroyed" in a more figurative sense, like being eternally separated from God. Some critics also argue that just because God *can* destroy the soul, that doesn't mean he necessarily *will*, and this may not be the point Jesus was making anyway, as evidenced by Luke omitting the part about destroying the soul.

bible.text: 28Don’t be afraid of those who kill the body, but are not able to kill the soul. Rather, fear him who is able to destroy both soul and body in Gehenna.

4“I tell you, my friends, don’t be afraid of those who kill the body, and after that have no more that they can do. 5But I will warn you whom you should fear. Fear him who after he has killed, has power to cast into Gehenna. Yes, I tell you, fear him.

evidence.head: The Second Death
evidence.short: The wicked will experience a 'second death'.
evidence.details:
Proponents argue that the most natural reading of this is that the wicked will simply cease to exist.

Critics argue that the second death could be a spiritual death, or eternal separation from God.

bible.text: 14Death and Hades were thrown into the lake of fire. This is the second death, the lake of fire. 15If anyone was not found written in the book of life, he was cast into the lake of fire.

8But for the cowardly, unbelieving, sinners, abominable, murderers, sexually immoral, sorcerers, idolaters, and all liars, their part is in the lake that burns with fire and sulfur, which is the second death.”

evidence.head: No Rest Day and Night
evidence.short: An angel announces that those who worship the beast will be tormented, the smoke of their torment goes up forever, and they have no rest day and night.
evidence.details:
Critics emphasize that the "smoke of their torment goes up forever and ever", which seems to indicate that the torment never ceases.

Proponents argue that the smoke might simply continue even after the wicked are destroyed, but that it could also be poetic exaggeration.

bible.text: 9Another angel, a third, followed them, saying with a great voice, “If anyone worships the beast and his image, and receives a mark on his forehead or on his hand, 10he also will drink of the wine of the wrath of God, which is prepared unmixed in the cup of his anger. He will be tormented with fire and sulfur in the presence of the holy angels and in the presence of the Lamb. 11The smoke of their torment goes up forever and ever. They have no rest day and night, those who worship the beast and his image, and whoever receives the mark of his name.

evidence.head: Eternal Destruction
evidence.short: Paul writes that the wicked will suffer 'eternal destruction away from the presence of the Lord'.
evidence.details:
Proponents argue that the most natural reading of this is that the wicked will simply cease to exist.

Critics emphasize that the wicked are described as being eternally separated from God's presence, which seems to imply that they will not simply cease to exist, but be "destroyed" in a figurative sense.

Proponents answer that being separated from God's presence is exactly what annihilation is, since God is the source of all existence.

evidence.head: Eternal Fire
evidence.short: The wicked are said to be punished with 'eternal fire'.
evidence.details:
Proponents argue that the fire itself could be eternal, even if the wicked are eventually destroyed by it. They emphasize that, while Jude says the angels are said to be punished with "eternal chains", the example for the wicked is the Egyptians, who are said to have been "destroyed" by Jesus.

Critics argue that the most natural reading of "eternal fire" and "eternal punishment" is that the fire never ceases to torment the wicked.

evidence.head: Old Testament References to Destruction
evidence.short: The wicked are often described as being destroyed or perishing in the Old Testament.
evidence.details:
Proponents argue that this is expected if annihilationism is true.

Critics argue that these passages are poetic and do not necessitate annihilation.

bible.text: 20But the wicked shall perish. The enemies of YHWH shall be like the beauty of the fields. They will vanish— vanish like smoke.
6A senseless man doesn’t know, neither does a fool understand this: 7though the wicked spring up as the grass, and all the evildoers flourish, they will be destroyed forever.

evidence.head: Church Fathers in Support of Annihilationism
evidence.short: Some early Church Fathers seem to support annihilationism.
evidence.details:
Proponents argue that this shows that annihilationism was at least a viable option in early Christianity.

Critics argue that these Fathers were in the minority, and that their views were later rejected by the Church.

ancient.author: Arnobius of Sicca
ancient.text: "And to make manifest what is unknown, this is man's real death, this which leaves nothing behind. For that which is seen by the eyes is only a separation of soul from body, not the last end — annihilation: this, I say, is man's real death, when souls which know not God shall be consumed in long-protracted torment with raging fire, into which certain fiercely cruel beings shall cast them, who were unknown before Christ, and brought to light only by His wisdom."

evidence.head: Church Fathers against Annihilationism
evidence.short: The majority of early Church Fathers did not teach annihilationism.
evidence.details:
Critics argue that this shows how that the early Church did not understand the eternal punishment as ending in non-existence.

Proponents caution that it might be possible for the majority to be wrong.

ancient.summary: On the Resurrection of the Flesh, Chapter 34
ancient.author: Tertullian
ancient.text: "We, however, so understand the soul's immortality as to believe it "lost," not in the sense of destruction, but of punishment, that is, in hell."

ancient.summary: The City of God, Book 21, Chapter 17
ancient.author: St. Augustine of Hippo
ancient.text: "I must now, I see, enter the lists of amicable controversy with those tender-hearted Christians who decline to believe that any, or that all of those whom the infallibly just Judge may pronounce worthy of the punishment of hell, shall suffer eternally, and who suppose that they shall be delivered after a fixed term of punishment, longer or shorter according to the amount of each man's sin."

evidence.short: The tree of life which Adam and Eve lost access to in Genesis is again accessible to the inhabitants of New Jerusalem in Revelation.
evidence.details:
Proponents argue that the tree of life was the means by which Adam and Eve were able to live forever before the Fall, and since only those who are saved have access to it again in New Jerusalem, it follows that the damned will not live forever.

Critics answer that Revelation is a vision, so any interpretation of it is speculative to some extent. Also, hell is not merely a physical punishment, but a spiritual one as well.

bible.summary: Genesis 3:22–23 (Losing access to the tree of life)
bible.text: 22YHWH God said, “Behold, the man has become like one of us, knowing good and evil. Now, lest he reach out his hand, and also take of the tree of life, and eat, and live forever—” 23Therefore YHWH God sent him out from the garden of Eden, to till the ground from which he was taken.

bible.summary: Revelation 22:2 (Gaining access to the tree of life)
bible.text: 2in the middle of its street. On this side of the river and on that was the tree of life, bearing twelve kinds of fruits, yielding its fruit every month. The leaves of the tree were for the healing of the nations.

evidence.short: Those who are considered worthy will be resurrected and can't die anymore.
evidence.details:
Proponents argue that this implies that those who are not worthy will not have eternal life and thus will be able to die.

Critics argue that the unworthy will also be resurrected, but to judgement, and this is a spiritual judgement too.

bible.text: 35But those who are considered worthy to attain to that age and the resurrection from the dead neither marry nor are given in marriage. 36For they can’t die any more, for they are like the angels and are children of God, being children of the resurrection.
29and will come out; those who have done good, to the resurrection of life; and those who have done evil, to the resurrection of judgment.

bible.summary: Daniel 12:2 (Resurrections of life vs. shame and everlasting contempt)
bible.text: 2Many of those who sleep in the dust of the earth will awake, some to everlasting life, and some to shame and everlasting contempt.

evidence.short: Jesus died for the sins of the ungodly, then came back to life.
evidence.details:
Proponents argue that if Jesus were taking the punishment on himself, that implies that the lost will die, perhaps after suffering temporarily, but not be tormented forever, after the resurrection.

Critics argue that we die once, but after that comes judgement, which seems to imply that the damned don't literally die more than once.

evidence.short: Isaiah (and Jesus) speaks of a worm that shall not die.
evidence.details:
Proponents argue that this is in the context of dead bodies, which suggests that the wicked will be dead.

Critics argue that they will be dead in one sense, but that they will still be suffering.

bible.text: 24“They will go out, and look at the dead bodies of the men who have transgressed against me; for their worm will not die, nor will their fire be quenched, and they will be loathsome to all mankind.”
44‘where their worm doesn’t die, and the fire is not quenched.’
2Many of those who sleep in the dust of the earth will awake, some to everlasting life, and some to shame and everlasting contempt.

evidence.short: Daniel says some will wake up to everlasting contempt.
evidence.details:
Critics argue that this makes more sense if they are aware of their fate the whole time.

Proponents argue that the contempt is everlasting to those who are saved, but that the lost are eventually destroyed.

bible.text: 2Many of those who sleep in the dust of the earth will awake, some to everlasting life, and some to shame and everlasting contempt.

evidence.short: The rich man was in torment in flames, yet able to speak.
evidence.details:
Critics argue that this suggests he was not being destroyed, and that he would remain like this forever.

Proponents argue that this is a parable, so the details may not be literally true of the afterlife, but even if they are, the destruction might simply be very slow and gradual.

bible.text: 23In Hades, he lifted up his eyes, being in torment, and saw Abraham far off, and Lazarus at his bosom. 24He cried and said, ‘Father Abraham, have mercy on me, and send Lazarus, that he may dip the tip of his finger in water and cool my tongue! For I am in anguish in this flame.’

evidence.short: The Catholic Church, the Eastern Orthodox Church, the Oriental Orthodox Church, the Assyrian Church of the East, as well as most Protestant groups, all reject annihilationism.
evidence.details:
Critics argue that this weighs heavily against annihilationism, because the judgement of the Church trumps individual Fathers.

Proponents caution that it might be possible for the entire Church to be wrong on something non-essential.
